Award.AwardTitle: Synergistic Studies of Raindrop Shapes, Oscillations and Orientations Using 2D-Video Disdrometer, Advanced Radar and Wind Tunnel
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research addresses a number of key science questions related to rain microstructure defined herein as the size, shape and orientation distributions of raindrops in a wide range of rain types and climatologies. Whilst great progress has been made in the understanding of drop size distribution variability, and there has been modest success in the use of "bulk" assumptions on mean drop shapes and orientation distributions, there are still variations in the raindrop shape distribution parameters and oscillation modes that are not fully understood. There are even fewer observations of the variability of the drop canting angle distribution. Knowledge of these rain microstructure characteristics is key to developing accurate polarimetric radar-based drop-size distribution and rain rate retrievals, and for electromagnetic wave attenuation-correction algorithms.

This research is observationally-driven and makes use of multiple 2D-video disdrometers in different locations (Huntsville, AL and Brisbane, AU) and advanced radars including the dual-polarized ARMOR radar in Huntsville, AL; the dual-wavelength/dual-polarized CP2 radar in Brisbane, and the dual-polarized CSU-CHILL radar near Greeley, CO. The world class vertical wind tunnel facility at the Johannes Gutenberg-Universit√§t in Mainz, Germany will be used for specialized observation of the time varying shapes and oscillation modes of freely "floating" drops, as well as an investigation into the time varying shapes of moderate-to-large drops after coalescing collisions with sub-millimetric sized drops.

The broader impacts of the study are: (a) better use of new observing capability resulting from the imminent polarimetric upgrade of the National Weather Service operational weather radar network and "gap-filler" X band radars for short range hydrological applications; (b) incorporation of new results to improve radar displays used by many TV stations in the US that are planning to upgrade their C-band systems to dual-polarization to improve severe weather forecasting, and (c) use of results on drop shapes and orientations by the national and international radiowave propagation community.

Firstly, it is much needed from the point of view of advanced weather radar systems, for determining accurate rainfall estimates and for retrieving microphysical parameters, for applications in meteorology and hydrology. This research is of direct importance to the network of advanced radar systems operated throughout the US by the National Weather Service. Secondly, information on the rain microstructure parameters is needed for predicting radiowave propagation effects, helping to determine rain attenuation and cross-polar effects along both terrestrial line-of-sight links and earth-space communication links. Understanding of drop size distribution has become relatively advanced in just a short amount of time due to advancement in, both, instrumentation and numerical modeling, yet work remains to be done in terms of drop shapes and orientations, particularly in different rain regimes or under varying meteorological conditions. Over the past 9 years, measurements using the 2D video disdrometer (2DVD; http://www.distrometer.at/) have yielded such information on drop shapes. Image 1 shows the shape measurements in x-y coordinates for four example drop sizes. Note these images represent rotational symmetry and that the smaller drops exhibit oblate-shape characteristics whereas the larger drops tend to have more flattened base. Note also finite width of the color contours can be largely attributed to drop oscillations, the inference being that the dominant mode of oscillation is the so-called symmetric mode. Image 2 summarizes the mean axis ratios (i.e. the ratio between the maximum vertical dimension and the maximum horizontal dimension) and their variability for all drop diameters in the 1.5 mm to 9 mm range. From previous studies, it is well known that there are three fundamental modes of drop oscillations but only the symmetric mode is dominant. A thorough examination of the 2DVD data from several locations have shown that in the vast majority of cases, the most √¶probable' shapes conform to those arising from the symmetric mode. There have been a few exceptions however, and our recent work has focused on conditions under which asymmetric oscillations can become significant, and if so, need to be addressed when estimating rainfall rates from the advanced weather radar systems. A synergistic approach is used with 2DVD measurements and simultaneous observations with advanced radars to investigate such events. Additionally, an advanced wind-tunnel facility at the Johannes Gutenberg University in Mainz, Germany, is used to study (a) drop oscillations forced by drop collisions and (b) due to aerodynamic flow considerations. Also addressed are the fall velocities of moderate-to-large sized drops since they are a critical component of deriving rain rate algorithms from radar as well as for numerical modeling of rain formation. We have established that for a given drop size, the fall velocities have a distribution of values rather than a fixed value which has been assumed so far in radar and numerical modeling studies.
